awd_titl_txt: Development of an Antarctic Gravity Wave Imaging Network (ANGWIN) for Collaborative Mesospheric Research
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal is funded to achieve the overarching goal quantifying the properties, variability and momentum fluxes of short period (<1 hour) mesospheric gravity waves and their dominant sources and effects over the Antarctic continent. These measurements are of high importance as gravity waves having small horizontal scales and large amplitudes and momentum fluxes are known to provide the majority of the mean and variable forcing in the mesosphere. Exploratory airglow studies from Antarctica have revealed a wealth of mesospheric wave activity and strong anisotropy in wave propagation headings and associated large differences in momentum fluxes at different sites. As these results suggest strong regional variability, the overall impact of gravity waves on the mesospheric dynamics over the vast Antarctic continent remains unknown. It is proposed to implement an international ANtarctic Gravity Wave Imaging Network (ANGWIN) that will provide an exceptional capability for investigating mesospheric gravity waves at selected sites encompassing the entire Antarctic continent. This network will capitalize on existing optical and radar measurement capabilities at eight well-established national research stations, strategically located around the continental coast at Halley Bay (UK), Syowa (Japan), Davis (Australia), McMurdo and South Pole (USA), and Rothera (UK), Ferraz (Brazil), Vernadsky (Ukraine) on the Antarctic Peninsula. As part of this project, the infrared (IR) all-sky mesospheric OH imagers will be installed at Davis, McMurdo, and Halley, and an all-sky near-IR imager at Vernadsky to augment the existing instrumentation and create an unprecedented capability for studying gravity wave properties at each site. It is important that ANGWIN create a novel opportunity for the international Antarctic research community to work together producing "high impact" science well above that which can be achieved individually. It is anticipated that the proposed collaborative imaging network will contribute substantially to graduate student education, both within the U.S. and abroad, and will lead to significant new research opportunities for graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant supported the development and initial research operations of an international coordinated Antarctic Gravity Wave Instrument Network (ANGWIN).  ANGWIN is a “scientist driven” program designed to establish a network of gravity wave observatories, operated by different nations working together in a spirit of close scientific collaboration. Our research plan has worked well bringing together colleagues from several international institutions (US, Japan, Australia, U.K. and Brazil), all with a common collaborative goal to better understand the effects of “gravity waves” on the Earth’s upper atmosphere over Antarctica. These waves are very important as they naturally conduct energy generated by large weather disturbances, such as fronts, storms and strong winds blowing over the high Antarctic peninsula mountain range into the Earth’s upper “mesosphere” (at an altitude of about 50 -70 miles) where they then break, like waves on a beach, depositing their energy.   Remote-sensing measurements by our ANGWIN network now regularly provides a new capability to study the large, continental-scale effects of these waves for the first time.

During this program our activities have focused on developing a new image measurement capability from the following sites: McMurdo (US), Syowa (Japan), Davis (Australia), Halley (UK), Rothera (UK), and Commandante Ferraz (Brazil). These international research stations are uniformly distributed around the continental perimeter, and together with ongoing measurements at South Pole Station they provide unprecedented coverage of the Antarctic gravity wave field and its variability during the long polar winter season.  We have succeeded in obtaining coordinated data from these field sites for the past 4 consecutive winters providing the most comprehensive data set on gravity waves anywhere in the world. 

An important feature of the ANGWIN program is that it brings together scientists and their students from several institutions and countries. We have conducted three very successful research workshops to date. The first was hosted by colleagues at The National Institute for Polar Research (NIPR) near Tokyo, Japan (March 2013).   Utah State University hosted the second workshop on campus at Logan, Utah (October 2014) (see group photograph), and most recently British Antarctic Survey (BAS) conducted a third workshop at Cambridge, UK (April 2016).  In total over 110 participants (including 35 students) with many repeat attendees and more than 120 scientific presentations.  Our ANGWIN program is flourishing with several planned collaborative research journal publications in the coming year. Further coordinated measurements will be made over the next 5 years, which together with future modelling, will lead to a much better understanding of the coupling of wave energy into the Earth’s near-space environment on a continental-wide scale over Antarctica, where such coordinated observations have previously been sparse.
